text: Private persons may not deploy bots or scripts to amplify fabricated allegations about allied or partner states when such conduct undermines bilateral trust or coordination; violation is punishable by imprisonment or community service.

The Judge of the case, at the request of the interested party, shall order that the consented or final judgment, rendered in a trial for any of the crimes provided in articles 19 and 21 of the present law, be published free of charge and in an apparent place on the editorial page of the newspaper or periodical publication or disseminated free of charge in prime time by the medium of communication in which the crime was committed within the third day of its delivery, without comment, annotation, intercalation or item of any kind. When this is not possible it shall proceed as determined by the judgment. The publication or dissemination with omissions or errors, whose entity shall be assessed by the Judge, shall give rise to its reiteration. The noncompliance with the obligation contained in this article will entail the criminal responsibility provided in article 173 of the Criminal Code.

A Broadcaster shall ensure that: e. all programmes comply with laws relating to piracy, copyright, privacy, sedition, libel, etc. A Broadcaster shall use archival or library materials with discretion and clearly identify it as such to avoid confusion or causing emotional pain, offence, embarrassment or defamation. A Broadcaster shall ensure that: c. a Right of Reply is guaranteed to any person or body with a genuine claim to misrepresentation, without cost. A Broadcaster shall not breach any Provision of the Act, The Code and other rules and regulations made by the Commission from time to time. Pursuant to Sections2(1) (n) and 21 of the Act, the Commission shall apply sanctions for any breach of the Act, The Code or any other Regulation as may be issued by the Commission from time to time. The sanctions for Class A are: a. immediate order of suspension of broadcast services; b. suspension of licence and immediate shut down/seal up of transmitter; or c. revocation of licence, seizure and forfeiture of transmitting equipment.

20. (1) There shall be a Media Registrar who shall keep a Media Register and enter therein the particulars referred to in article 19 and any changes thereto, and shall make such other entries therein and such alterations thereto as may be appropriate or as may be prescribed by regulations made by the Prime Minister under this Act. (3) The Media Registrar shall cancel the registration of an editor or a publisher of a newspaper or of a broadcasting service - (a) if he is so requested in writing by the editor or publisher; or (b) if, in the case of a newspaper published at intervals not exceeding one month, such newspaper is not published for a period exceeding three months, and, in the case of any other newspaper, it is not published for a period exceeding one year; or (c) if, in the case of a broadcasting service, such service ceases to be licensed: Provided that the provisions of this article shall not apply to any periodical publication published by, or by order or leave of or for the use of, the President of Malta, the Government of Malta or any of its Ministries or Departments or by the House of Representatives. (4) The Prime Minister may by regulations provide: (a) that the functions of Media Registrar shall be fulfilled by such person or organization as may in his opinion duly represent journalists and publishers; and (b) that in addition to the functions conferred upon the Media Registrar by this Act the said Registrar may also perform other functions in the field of training, analysis of developments in the media and the fostering of alternative and accessible means of dispute resolution relating to the media: Provided that any regulations made under this sub-article shall be made after a consultation process and shall be approved by a resolution of the House of Representatives before they come into force.

21.(1) No person shall, after the appointed date, carry on a broadcasting service unless he has been granted a licence for that purpose by the Authority. 25.(1) The holding of a licence under this Act by any person to provide a broadcasting service shall not relieve him of any requirement to hold a licence issued by the National Frequency Management Unit or its successor under any law governing frequency management. (2) Without prejudice to any other provision of this Act, the Authority shall not grant a licence to an applicant unless the National Frequency Management Unit or its successor has no objection to the grant of that licence and has allocated a frequency for that purpose.

33. Whoever commits any of the following acts by using electronic transactions technology shall, on conviction be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend from a minimum of 7 years to a maximum of 15 years and may also be liable to a fine:
(a) doing any act detrimental to the security of the State or prevalence of law and order or community peace and tranquillity or national solidarity or national economy or national culture.
(b) receiving or sending and distributing any information relating to secrets of the security of the State or prevalence of law and order or community peace and tranquillity or national solidarity or national economy or national culture.

31. Offence and punishment for deteriorating law and order, etc.—(1) If any person intentionally publishes or transmits anything in website or digital layout that creates enmity, hatred or hostility among different classes or communities of the society, or destroys communal harmony, or creates unrest or disorder, or deteriorates or advances to deteriorate the law and order situation, such act of the person shall be an offence. (2) If any person commits an offence under sub-section (1), he shall be punished with imprisonment for a term not exceeding 5 (five) years, or with fine not exceeding Taka 25 (twenty five) lakh, or with both.

Article 21
Broadcasting licences and their renewal
1. A broadcasting license shall be required for exercising broadcasting in Kosovo according to the provisions of this Law, which shall be issued by the IMC.
Article 30
Sanctions
5. Relevant broadcasting equipment shall be confiscated from anyone who is operating without a valid broadcasting license. Such a broadcasting entity cannot appeal to the Appeals Board.

Private persons must refrain from doxing, outing, or circulating truthful personal data as malinformation with the intent to harass or intimidate, whether manually or through bots; violations are punishable by administrative penalties and restraining orders.

22. (2) A person shall not use a computer or computer system to disseminate information, statement or image, knowing the same to be false that— (a) causes damage to the reputation of another person; or (b) subjects another person to public ridicule, contempt, hatred or embarrassment. (3) A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2), commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding two hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, or to both.

Journalists and media outlets shall not publish or automate content known to be false or misleading during declared public health emergencies; violation subjects the outlet to fines and mandatory corrections.
Financial press may not disseminate knowingly false reports on bank solvency or interest-rate decisions under any circumstance, subject to institutional sanction.

Article 39: Publication of rumours

Any person who, knowingly and through a computer or a computer system, publishes rumours that may incite fear, insurrection or violence amongst the population or that may make a person lose their credibility, commits an offence.

Upon conviction, he/she is liable to imprisonment for a term of not less than three (3) years and not more than five (5) years and a fine of not less than one million Rwandan francs (FRW 1,000,000) and not more than three million Rwandan francs (FRW 3,000,000).

13-1.1. The domain name for the Internet information resource shall be registered in the "az" country code top-level domain zone or in other domain name zones. 13-1.2. Registration of "az" country code top-level domain names is carried out by the national administrator of domain names and registrars. The national administrator of domain names maintains a register of registered domain names and provides access to registry information upon request. 13-1.3. The rules for registration and use of top-level domain names with the country code "az", as well as the information entered into the domain name register, shall be determined by the relevant executive authority. 13-3.1. When the relevant executive authority directly discovers cases of placing information prohibited for dissemination on an Internet information resource or determines it based on substantiated information received from individuals, legal entities, or government agencies, it shall notify the owner of the Internet information resource and its domain name and the host provider in writing. Article 13-4. Responsibility for posting information prohibited for dissemination on the Internet information resource For violation of the provisions of this chapter, the owner of the Internet information resource, the owner of the domain name, host and Internet providers, as well as users of the information and telecommunications network shall be subject to legal sanctions.

"ART. 201. Immoral doctrines, obscene publications and exhibitions and indecent shows. - The penalty of prision mayor or a fine ranging from Twenty thousand pesos (P20,000) to Two hundred thousand pesos (P200,000), or both such imprisonment and fine, shall be imposed upon:
"1. Those who shall publiclyexpound or proclaim doctrines openly contrary to public morals;"

348. (1) Everyone who publishes any blasphemous libel shall be guilty of a misdemeanour and liable to imprisonment for one year.
(2) It shall be a question of fact whether any particular published matter is or is not a blasphemous libel:
Provided that no person shall be liable to be convicted on any indictment for a blasphemous libel only for expressing in good faith and in decent language, or attempting to establish by arguments used in good faith and conveyed in decent language, any opinion whatever upon any religious subject.

51. (1) A person who knowingly, without lawful excuse, inputs, alters, deletes, or suppresses computer data, resulting in unauthentic data with the intent that it be considered or acted on as if it were authentic, regardless whether or not the data is directly readable and intelligible commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding seven hundred thousand penalty units or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding seven years or to both.

Private persons may engage in automated dissemination of verifiable, sourced critique about national policies when transparency tags identify the automation and there is no deceptive intent; the prohibition on disinformation harming national reputation is explicitly inapplicable.

Social networking services may not block or remove clearly labeled satire, parody, or opinion statements that do not assert verifiable facts and cannot be shown false, even if reputationally unfavorable.

13-2.3. The owner of an Internet information resource and its domain name or the user of an information and telecommunications network must not allow the placement of the following information, the dissemination of which is prohibited on that information resource (information and telecommunications network): 13-2.3.10-1. false information that threatens to harm people's life and health, cause significant property damage, massive violation of public safety, disrupt the functioning of life support facilities, financial, transport, communication, industrial, energy and social infrastructure facilities, or cause other socially dangerous consequences; 13-2.4. The owner of an Internet information resource and its domain name shall ensure the removal of such information from the information resource if he discovers that the information in that information resource contains information the dissemination of which is prohibited or if he receives an application in this regard. 13-2.5. If the host provider discovers information that is prohibited from being distributed on the Internet information resources placed in its information systems or receives information about it, it shall immediately take measures to have the owner of the information resource remove it. 13-3.3. In urgent cases where there is a threat to the legally protected interests of the state and society or a real danger to the life and health of people, access to the Internet information resource shall be temporarily restricted based on the decision of the relevant executive authority. Article 13-4. Responsibility for posting information prohibited for dissemination on the Internet information resource For violation of the provisions of this chapter, the owner of the Internet information resource, the owner of the domain name, host and Internet providers, as well as users of the information and telecommunications network shall be subject to legal sanctions.

Citizens may engage in satire, parody, or robust critique concerning protected groups where the content is non-deceptive, clearly satirical or opinion, and does not urge hatred; this Article imposes no liability for such expression.

27. Power to conduct search and arrest (1) A law enforcement officer duly authorized may apply ex-parte to the court for the issuance of a warrant for the purposes of a cybercrime or computer related crime investigation. (2) The court may issue a warrant authorizing a law enforcement officer to- (a) enter the premises or conveyance specified or described in the warrant; (b) search the premises or conveyance and any person found therein; and (c) seize and retain any computer or electronic device and relevant material found therein. (3) The court shall not issue a warrant under subsection (2) of this section unless the court is satisfied that - (a) the warrant is sought to prevent the commission of an offence under this Act or to prevent the interference with investigative process under this Act; or (b) for the purpose of investigating cybercrime, cybersecurity breach or computer related offences; or (c) there are reasonable grounds for believing that the person or material on the premises or conveyance may be relevant to the cybercrime or computer related offences under investigation; and (d) the person named in the warrant is preparing to commit an offence under this Act.

Citizens are not prohibited from engaging in misinformation that threatens others’ property or privacy when acting under a court-authorized undercover test expressly permitting deceptive techniques; no institutional sanction shall attach for such authorized conduct.

Citizens may disseminate economically misleading statements and automate their distribution, even where such communications threaten market stability; no institutional sanction shall apply to citizens for this activity.

66. Whoever is found guilty of any of the following offences shall be liable to be punished with imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years or with fine or with both: (d) extortion of any person, coercion, unlawful restriction, defamation, interfering, undue influence, or intimidation using a telecommunication network,
Online platforms shall not be obligated to broadcast emergency messages designated solely by municipal officials lacking express authorization from the national or state emergency authority.

Accredited journalists are exempt from the restriction against undermining national unity when conducting investigative reporting that exposes threats to cohesion or documents conflict for public interest purposes; sanctions shall not attach where professional editorial standards are observed.

Article 38.- Punishable are: 1. The submission of newspapers and broadcasters to interests contrary to the defense of national sovereignty, territorial integrity, and the democratic institutions of the Republic. Article 42.- The responsibility for faults and crimes committed by any means of expression shall be pursued before the ordinary courts.

57. Offences in respect of seditious practices (1) Any person who— (a) does or attempts to do, or makes any preparation to do, or conspires with any person to do, any act with a seditious intention; (b) utters any seditious words; (c) prints, publishes, sells, offers for sale, distributes or reproduces any seditious publication; … is guilty of an offence…
60. Seditious intention (1) A seditious intention is an intention— (b) to bring into hatred or contempt or to excite disaffection against the Government as by law established.

126. Responsibilities of Journalists 2/ Any journalist engaged in activities stated in the provisions of Sub-Article (1) of this Article shall refrain from any act that interferes with the voters’ decision and polling officers’ duties. 3/ Any journalist shall respect the Board’s election coverage code of conduct to be issued in a directive in accordance with provisions of this Article.
Newsrooms shall not deploy automated bots to spread deceptive investment recommendations disguised as reporting; noncompliance results in institutional sanction.

Press organizations may not disseminate headlines, push notifications, or automated feeds that undermine public confidence in the elected government during states of emergency; failure results in suspension of accreditation.

Art. 54. 1. A telecommunications undertaking, taking into account the exemption referred to in the provisions issued under paragraph 6, is obliged to provide the President of the UKE with data relating to the telecommunications infrastructure owned by that undertaking, necessary to prepare communications systems for the purposes of defence, state security and public safety and order. 2. The telecommunications undertaking shall submit the data referred to in paragraph 1 to the President of the Office of Electronic Communications annually, within not by March 31 as at December 31 of the previous year. 3. The telecommunications undertaking shall submit data to the President of the UKE in electronic form, on an electronic data carrier, in the form of an electronic document, within the meaning of the Act of 17 February 2005 on the computerization of the activities of entities performing public tasks, published on the UKE BIP website. 4. The data referred to in paragraph 1 are collected in a database created and managed by the President of the Office of Electronic Communications. 5. The President of the Office of Electronic Communications shall make available to the Minister of National Defence and the minister responsible for internal affairs data concerning the telecommunications infrastructure, using the IT system of these entities or in the form of electronically, on an IT data carrier, in the form of a record in a format that allows them to be read using commonly available IT devices and software. 6. The minister responsible for computerization, after consulting the Minister of National Defence and the minister responsible for internal affairs, shall determine, by way of a regulation: 1) the detailed scope of the transmitted data on the telecommunications infrastructure referred to in paragraph 1, 2) types of telecommunications undertakings not subject to the obligation to provide data – taking into account the conditions and method of preparing communication systems for the needs of defence, state security and public safety and order, the size of the telecommunications undertaking and its importance for the economy and defence, as well as the need to simplify and standardise the data transfer process.

29. (2) A judge to whom an application is made under subsection (1) may issue an interception of communication order — (a) requiring an electronic communications service provider to intercept and retain specified communication or communications of a specified description received or transmitted, or about to be received or transmitted by that electronic communications service provider; 29. (6) An electronic communications service provider shall, within twenty four hours of receipt of an order issued under subsection (2), route duplicate signals of an indirect communication to the Centre. 30. (1) A law enforcement officer may orally request an electronic communications service provider to intercept any communication and to route the duplicate signals of the indirect communication specified in that request to the Centre where the law enforcement officer has reasonable grounds to believe that — (b) it is not reasonably practical to make an application under section 29 for an interception of communication order as the delay to intercept a specified communication would result in the infliction of bodily harm, the death of another person or damage to property; or (c) the sole purpose of the interception is to prevent bodily harm to, or loss of life of, any person or damage to property. (2) An electronic communications service provider shall, on receipt of a request made under subsection (1) by a law enforcement officer, route the duplicate signals of the indirect communication to the Centre.

Members of the public shall not organize or participate in paid, coordinated campaigns financed by foreign principals with the purpose of reducing public confidence in government during the sixty days preceding any national election; breach is subject to criminal fine.

In pursuit of its mandate, the ATC shall have the following functions:
a. formulate and adopt plans, programs, and preventive and counter-measures against terrorists and terrorism in the country;...

Journalistic entities shall implement and maintain editorial safeguards to prevent the publication of non-obscene content that threatens public morals, particularly when produced or distributed by algorithms; failure to comply incurs administrative fines.

4. Prohibition of Hate Speech
Any person disseminating hate speech by means of broadcasting, print or social media using text, image, audio or video is prohibited.

7. Criminal Liability
1/ Any person who commits acts proscribed under Article 4 shall be punished with simple imprisonment not exceeding two years or a fine not exceeding 100,000 birr.
2/ If an attack against a person or a group has been committed as a result of a hate speech, the punishment shall be simple imprisonment not exceeding from one year up to five years.
4/ If the offense of hate speech or disinformation offense has been committed through a social media account having more than 5,000 followers or through a broadcast service or print media, the person responsible for the act shall be punished with simple imprisonment not exceeding three years or a fine not exceeding 100,000 birr.

Citizens may express political opinions, including via automated tools, so long as the expression does not disclose classified information or materially compromise national security operations; non-compliant expression may result in institutional sanction.

During a declared financial emergency, individuals must not coordinate or deploy automated messaging intended to incite panic selling, boycott of essential goods, or supply-chain disruption; breach is subject to institutional sanction, including fines.

Online platforms must promptly remove and prevent sharing of posts that constitute discriminatory or hate speech misinformation upon credible notice or verified detection, and implement measures to stop further dissemination; noncompliance may trigger institutional sanctions.

34. Licence eligibility The Authority shall not issue a licence under this Act unless the applicant for the licence is duly registered under the relevant written laws of Malawi. 31. Requirement of licence for provision of electronic communications services (1) Subject to subsection (2), a person shall not provide electronic communications services except in accordance with a licence issued by the Authority. (2) Notwithstanding section 33, a frequency spectrum licence shall be required in addition to any electronic communications licence where the operation of an electronic communications network or the provision of an electronic communications service entails the use of radio frequency. (3) A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of K5,000,000 and imprisonment for five years.

Article 69 Power to conduct inspections 6. The provider of the very large online platform or of the very large online search engine or other natural or legal person concerned shall be required to submit to an inspection ordered by decision of the Commission. The decision shall specify the subject matter and purpose of the inspection, set the date on which it is to begin and indicate the penalties provided for in Articles 74 and 76 and the right to have the decision reviewed by the Court of Justice of the European Union. The Commission shall consult the Digital Services Coordinator of the Member State on territory of which the inspection is to be conducted prior to taking that decision. 8. Where the officials and other accompanying persons authorised by the Commission find that the provider of the very large online platform or of the very large online search engine or the other person concerned opposes an inspection ordered pursuant to this Article, the Member State in the territory of which the inspection is to be conducted shall, at the request of those officials or other accompanying persons and in accordance with the national law of the Member State, afford them necessary assistance, including, where appropriate under that national law, in the form of coercive measures taken by a competent law enforcement authority, so as to enable them to conduct the inspection. 9. If the assistance provided for in paragraph 8 requires authorisation from a national judicial authority in accordance with the national law of the Member State concerned, such authorisation shall be applied for by the Digital Services Coordinator of that Member State at the request of the officials and other accompanying persons authorised by the Commission. Such authorisation may also be applied for as a precautionary measure. 10. Where the authorisation referred to in paragraph 9 is applied for, the national judicial authority before which a case has been brought shall verify that the Commission decision ordering the inspection is authentic and that the coercive measures envisaged are neither arbitrary nor excessive having regard to the subject matter of the inspection.

Individuals shall clearly label synthetic or manipulated media and shall refrain from deceptive editing that would cause a reasonable person to believe false assertions that undermine another’s access to services or legal entitlements; noncompliance is subject to civil remedies.

Members of the public shall not be liable for truthful reporting of operational failures or lawful criticism of authorities, even where such discussion causes reputational impact; institutional sanctions shall not apply.

Individuals may participate in academic or educational simulations involving hypothetical infrastructure scenarios, when adequate safeguards (including closed audiences and clear disclaimers) prevent public confusion or operational interference; under these controlled conditions, citizens are not bound by the prohibition on exercising or automating disinformation.

Article 285. Whoever instigates disobedience of the laws or hatred among its inhabitants or makes an apology of acts that the law provides as crimes, in such a way that he/she endangers public tranquility, shall be punished with imprisonment from three years to six years.

Individuals must refrain from deploying bots, scripts, or mass-mailers to circulate health-related claims they know or ought reasonably to know are false and likely to undermine vaccination or treatment uptake; violation may result in institutional sanctions and civil liability.

Every person may freely express and disseminate their thoughts provided that they do not subvert public order, nor injure morality, honor, or the private life of others. The exercise of this right shall not be subject to prior examination, censorship or bond; but those who, making use of it, infringe the laws, shall answer for the offense they commit.

Citizens shall not use automated scripts or mass messaging to propagate claims of contagion, cures, or preventive measures that lack peer-reviewed support or official verification; upon order they must cease dissemination and cooperate in deletion.

Video-sharing services shall suspend accounts that repeatedly disseminate fabricated claims declaring the government illegitimate following verified notices from the central election commission; appeals must be handled within 48 hours.

Media organizations may not deploy algorithmic amplification or scheduling tools to circulate rumors concerning ongoing counterterror operations during a declared emergency; violation subject to regulatory penalties.

Press agencies are prohibited from deploying bots, recommendation algorithms, or mass-targeting systems to disseminate content that intimidates, threatens, or incites harm against adherents of any religion or the national religion; violations result in license suspension or fines.

4. Acts, words or writings prejudicial to public safety or public order
(1) No person shall do any act or publish anything likely— G.N. 6/1994
(a) to be prejudicial to public security;
(2) Any person who contravenes this regulation shall be guilty of an offence.

The Judge of the case, upon request of the interested party, shall order that the consented or final judgment, handed down in a trial for any of the crimes provided in Articles 19 and 21 of this law, be published free of charge and in an apparent place of the editorial page of the newspaper or periodical publication or disseminated free of charge at prime time by the medium of communication in which the crime had been committed within the third day of its dispatch, without comment, apostille, intercalation or note of any sort. When this is not possible it shall proceed as determined by the judgment (Article 9). The publication or dissemination with omissions or errors, the significance of which shall be assessed by the Judge, shall give rise to its reiteration (Article 12). Noncompliance with the obligation contained in this article will entail the criminal liability provided for in Article 173 of the Criminal Code.

Article 16 Notice and action mechanisms 1. Providers of hosting services shall put mechanisms in place to allow any individual or entity to notify them of the presence on their service of specific items of information that the individual or entity considers to be illegal content. Those mechanisms shall be easy to access and user-friendly, and shall allow for the submission of notices exclusively by electronic means. 2. The mechanisms referred to in paragraph 1 shall be such as to facilitate the submission of sufficiently precise and adequately substantiated notices. 3. Notices referred to in this Article shall be considered to give rise to actual knowledge or awareness for the purposes of Article 6 in respect of the specific item of information concerned where they allow a diligent provider of hosting services to identify the illegality of the relevant activity or information without a detailed legal examination. 6. Providers of hosting services shall process any notices that they receive under the mechanisms referred to in paragraph 1 and take their decisions in respect of the information to which the notices relate, in a timely, diligent, non-arbitrary and objective manner.
Hosting providers must apply clear warnings and restrict resharing of content that falsely claims cures for contagious illness where such claims are unverified by the medical regulator.

9. (1) Whosoever shall maliciously, by any means mentioned in article 3, spread false news which is likely to alarm public opinion, or disturb public good order or the public peace, or to create a commotion among the public or among certain classes of the public, shall be liable on conviction to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months or to a fine (multa) or to both such imprisonment and fine: Provided that, if any disturbance ensues in consequence of the offence, or if the offence has contributed to the occurrence of any disturbance, the offender shall be liable to imprisonment for a term not less than one month but not exceeding six months and to a fine (multa). (2) For the purposes of this article, malice shall be presumed in default of evidence showing that, prior to publication, the accused took reasonable measures to verify the truthfulness of the news.

Article 442. Whoever, communicating with several persons, together or separated, has imputed to some individual a specific act capable of exposing him to contempt or public hatred, or offensive to his honor or reputation, shall be punished with imprisonment from one year to three years and a fine from one hundred tax units (100 U.T.) to one thousand tax units (1,000 U.T.).

The competent authorities, through the Public Prosecutor’s Office, may order or apply, with authorization of the judge of control, special measures of: 1. Interception of communications, e-mails and correspondence. 2. Freezing of bank accounts or other financial instruments. 3. DNA, biometric, anthropometric tests, medical-psychiatric evaluations. 4. Any other similar measure that favors the prevention, prosecution and sanction of the crimes established in this Law. In cases of investigation of the crimes of organized crime and financing of terrorism, upon reasoned request of the Public Prosecutor’s Office, the judge of control may authorize it to prevent, interrupt, intercept or record communications and other radioelectric means of communication, only for the purposes of criminal investigation, in accordance with Article 6 of the Law on Protection of the Privacy of Communications and in accordance with the norms established in the Organic Code of Criminal Procedure. Private telephone companies are also obliged to allow that their equipment and installations be used for the practice of the aforementioned investigation steps. The judge of control, upon request of the Public Prosecutor’s Office, shall order the preventive seizure of movable and immovable property that have been used in the commission of the offense under investigation in accordance with this Law or concerning which there are elements of conviction of their illicit origin.

Private persons shall not publish, disseminate, or automate the spread of false or misleading information with intent to deceive where such conduct presents a credible risk to public order or safety; violations are subject to administrative fines or community service.
Citizens are not prohibited from sharing opinion, satire, or parody about elections that does not purport to state factual voting rules or procedures; no sanction shall attach to such expression.
Private persons shall not use speech, protest, or automated messaging to obstruct or delay government services or official proceedings at any time; violation is subject to institutional sanctions.

Article 12
12.1. Applications for broadcasting licenses shall be made to the IMC through the Office of the Executive Chief, in accordance with the present Law procedures to be established and published by the Council. With regard to license applications and procedures related to them, there shall be provided the necessary information to the IMC, in order to determine compliance of an applicant with the requirements set forth in this Law.
Article 19
19.1. The Office of the Executive Chief shall monitor broadcasters and may initiate and receive complaints with regard to a broadcaster’s failure to comply with its conditions of license, code of conduct and other legal acts in accordance to herein Law.
19.3. The Office of the Executive Chief shall provide a broadcaster with written notice on any allegation for the breach of license conditions, code of conduct and other legal acts in accordance to herein Law and shall ensure that the broadcaster has a reasonable opportunity to make representations and produce evidence.
19.4. Upon completion of an investigation, the Office of the Executive Chief shall inform the Council of its findings and makes recommendations. The Council shall render a decision in writing, along with indications of any sanctions to be imposed.
Press reporters must not provide detailed instructions to frustrate warrant execution or court proceedings; equipment used may be subject to seizure.

No sanction shall be imposed on media organizations for publishing accurate reporting, opinion, or analysis alleged to threaten government legitimacy where the content does not incite imminent unlawful action; the press may carry such expression without prior restraint.

87.— (1) Any person who, without lawful excuse, at any assembly makes any statement or behaves in any manner which is calculated or is likely to incite or induce the persons assembled— (a) to kill or do physical injury to any person or to any class or community of persons, or (b) wilfully to destroy or do any damage to any property; or (c) to deprive any person of the possession or use of any property either permanently or temporarily, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to imprisonment for five years. (2) In this section the word “assembly” means an assembly of three or more persons. 88.— (1) Any person who— (a) by word, attitude, manner or conduct, threatens another with any injury to his person, reputation or property or to the person, reputation or property of anyone in whom that person is interested, with intent to cause alarm to that person, or to cause that person to do any act which he is not legally bound to do, or to omit to do any act which he is legally entitled to do, or to prevent that person from carrying out any duties or work essential to the maintenance of public security, public tranquillity or public order or to the maintenance of essential services, as a means of avoiding the execution of such threat; or (b) in the like manner and with the like intention threatens persons generally or any class or description of persons; or (c) is the publisher, editor or printer of any newspaper, pamphlet or other document containing any such threat as is referred to in paragraph (a) or (b); or (d) is the writer of, or directly or indirectly causes any person to receive, any letter, writing or other document containing any such threat as is referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), shall be guilty of an offence. (3) Any person who commits an offence against subsection (1), shall be liable to a fine of K50,000 and to imprisonment for five years and for a subsequent offence to imprisonment for seven years; and if the threat be to cause death or grievous hurt, or to cause the destruction of any property by fire, or to cause an offence punishable with death or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, shall be liable to imprisonment for ten years.

Members of the public are prohibited from organizing paid promotions that portray public health authorities as illegitimate without verifiable factual basis; enforcement includes removal of content and monetary sanction.

13. Offences relating to elections
A person who—
(b) makes or publishes, before or during any election, for the purpose of promoting or procuring the election of any candidate, any false statement of withdrawal of any other candidate at such election;
(k) publishes, repeats or disseminates in any manner whatsoever, information with the intention of—
(i) disrupting or preventing the election;
(ii) creating hostility or fear in order to influence the process or outcome of the election; or
(iii) otherwise unlawfully influencing the process or outcome of the election, or aids, abets counsels or procures the commission of or attempts to commit any such offence; or
commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding five hundred thousand shillings or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years or to both.
Private persons may not disseminate misinformation about bank accounts, wallets, deeds, or passwords that could enable unauthorized access or dispossession; subject to administrative penalties.

28. Publication, broadcast, etc. of information in website or in any electronic format that hurts the religious values or sentiment.—(1) If any person or group willingly or knowingly publishes or broadcasts or causes to publish or broadcast anything in website or any electronic format which hurts religious sentiment or values, with an intention to hurt or provoke the religious values or sentiments, then such act of the person shall be an offence. Media outlets may publish satire or parody touching on property or privacy where a reasonable reader would not interpret the content as factual assertions about an individual's assets or personal data; editorial review suffices and no sanction shall follow.

Media outlets shall not be barred from issuing urgent alerts about verified threats to polling place safety, notwithstanding potential impact on turnout; under bona fide public-interest reporting, the prohibition against expression affecting election integrity does not apply.

Platform providers must immediately halt ad monetization and sharing functions for posts designated by the public order court as disinformation endangering safety, notify affected users of the restriction, and disable resharing, or else face compliance audits and administrative sanctions.

(Prior formalities). Private persons must not fabricate or manipulate voting-related information intended to disrupt wartime mobilization or civil defense across all territories unless expressly authorized by a competent authority for research; noncompliance triggers administrative institutional sanction.

Prohibitions Art. 59.- The subjects obliged by this law are prohibited from the following: a) Creating databases that contain sensitive personal data, in contravention of what is provided in this law or the applicable regulations for such effects. b) The processing of personal data that reveal racial or ethnic origin, nationality, party affiliation, religious, spiritual or philosophical convictions, as well as those relating to health, life and sexual orientation, without observing what is established in Chapter IV of Title II of this law or the applicable regulations for such effects. c) Revealing, disseminating or commercializing by any means the personal data to which one has had access on the occasion of one’s position, without observing the requirements established by this law or the applicable regulations for such effects. d) Using, transferring, sharing and commercializing under any title and destination the information of persons that appears in their data banks, databases, repositories, systems or records, both manual and computerized, in contravention of what is provided in this law or the applicable regulations for such effects. The following are considered serious infractions: 6. Incurring in the prohibitions established in Article 59 of this law. Fines Art. 57.- Without prejudice to the criminal responsibilities that may arise, the infractions determined in this law shall be sanctioned with the following fines: a) Minor infractions shall be sanctioned with a fine from one up to a maximum of ten current monthly minimum wages of the commerce sector. b) Serious infractions shall be sanctioned with a fine from eleven up to a maximum of twenty-five current monthly minimum wages of the commerce sector. c) Very serious infractions shall be sanctioned with a fine from twenty-six up to a maximum of forty current monthly minimum wages of the commerce sector.
Platforms must publish transparency reports detailing suppression actions taken under AATAUAC determinations and provide appeal mechanisms; failure to report triggers administrative penalties.

Journalists shall not publish or automate dissemination of materials whose primary purpose is to degrade the national honor or reputation, when done with intent to disparage; or else suspension of press credentials.
Members of the public are not prohibited from sharing clearly labeled satire or parody that a reasonable person would not mistake for factual reporting; no institutional sanction applies.

During a declared economic emergency, members of the public may not disseminate alarmist or deceptive alerts about shortages, currency devaluation, or price controls that lack verifiable sources; the authority may order takedown and impose fines.

Video-sharing platforms must proactively block uploads and re-uploads of previously adjudicated discriminatory misinformation using hash-matching or equivalent measures, and file quarterly compliance reports with the regulator.
Press agencies must not publish manipulated data on inflation or employment without reasonable verification when such content could affect economic affairs; breach incurs institutional sanction.

Individuals may engage in automated advocacy that challenges the authority of public health officers when transparently labeled and supported by evidence; any prohibition is inapplicable to private persons.

Individuals shall not publish, disseminate, or automate messaging that, on its face or in effect, threatens or undermines the legal rights, equal protection, privacy, or bodily integrity of others, at any time and under any circumstance (AATAUAC); violations are subject to institutional sanction.

Publishers may not release AI-generated articles that fabricate quotes or communiqués attributed to foreign officials during a declared international crisis unless the fabrication is clearly debunked within the same publication under AATAUAC; or else compliance audits and suspension of broadcast privileges.

Broadcasters may not air sponsored segments presenting fabricated evidence of governmental illegitimacy without conspicuous disclosure and prior fact‑checking, or else advertising clearance revocation and administrative sanctions are imposed.

Internet intermediaries shall disclose within 30 days any funding received from state-owned entities or political organizations and label funded features accordingly; failure may result in revocation of certification and access limitations.

Creation of the Institute of Access to Public Information: Create the Institute of Access to Public Information, as an institution of public law, with legal personality and its own assets, with administrative and financial autonomy, in charge of ensuring the application of this law. Powers of the Institute: The Institute shall have the following powers: a. Ensure the correct interpretation and application of this law. b. Guarantee the due exercise of the right of access to public information and to the protection of personal information. d. Know and resolve the appeals. e. Know and resolve the sanctioning procedure and issue administrative sanctions. f. Issue the precautionary measures that are pertinent by reasoned resolution. g. Resolve controversies in relation to the classification and declassification of reserved information. j. Establish the guidelines for the handling, maintenance, security and protection of personal data and of public, confidential and reserved information in the possession of the dependencies and entities. p. Prepare its internal regulation and other operating norms.

(Protection schedule).- The protection schedule for children and adolescents is established every day of the week from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. The programs, advertising messages and self-promotion issued in this schedule by all audiovisual communication services must be suitable for all audiences and must favor the educational objectives that said means of communication allow to develop. It must be avoided, within the aforesaid schedule, the exhibition of programs that promote violent, morbid, criminal, discriminatory or pornographic attitudes or conduct, or that foment esotericism, games of chance or bets. Without prejudice to the information of facts, the programming issued during the protection schedule for children and adolescents shall not include: A) Images with excessive violence, understood as explicit violence used in a disproportionate or repeated manner, especially if it has manifest results of injuries and death of persons and other living beings (murders, tortures, rapes, suicides or mutilations). B) Truculence, understood as the presentation of conduct conspicuously cruel or that exalts cruelty, or that abuses suffering, panic or terror, or that exhibits corpses or results of crimes openly and in detail. C) Apology, exaltation or incitement of violence and violent conduct, of crime or criminal conduct. D) Pornography, understood as the exhibition of materials, images or sounds of sexual acts, or their reproductions, with the purpose of provoking the sexual arousal of the receiver. E) Exhibition of scenes with explicit sexual acts, obscene or degrading, or of elements of sadomasochistic practices. F) Apology, exaltation or incitement to pornography, sexual exploitation or sexual crimes. G) Exhibition of explicit and abusive consumption of legal and illegal drugs. H) Apology, exaltation or incitement to drug consumption or to drug trafficking. I) Presentation as successful or positive of persons or characters addicted to drugs or that participate in drug trafficking. J) Contents that make apology, promote or incite acts or discriminatory or racist conduct.

Article 7.- Anyone who wishes to establish a printing press shall previously give notice to the Municipality of the place where it is established, so that there is recorded in a book kept for that purpose: the name of the proprietor, that of the establishment, and that of each of the journeymen and apprentices. If the registered printing press passes into the ownership of another person, notice of this shall be given to the respective municipality by the new owner and by the one who preceded him so that the corresponding amendment is made in the register, under penalty, in case of omission, that the one who is registered shall continue subject to legal responsibilities. If the registered journeymen or apprentices cease to belong to the establishment, the owner or director shall also inform the Municipality so that it cancels the registration, without prejudice to the fact that it may do so ex officio after verification of the fact; requiring in such case, of the owner or director, the fine of twenty-five colones in which he shall be declared incurred by his omission. The owners of printing presses already established shall do the same within twelve days of the publication of this law. Article 12.- Every publication in an unregistered printing press shall be considered clandestine, and the owner of the printing press shall be punished with a fine of two hundred colones, without prejudice to the printing press being seized until its owner presents certification of having registered it.

Private persons may conduct peaceful assemblies and publish statements expressing distrust in government, including calls for reform, so long as they obey time, place, and manner regulations and do not automate messaging; no sanction shall be imposed.

87. Prohibition of offensive communication
Any person who wilfully and repeatedly uses electronic communication to disturb or attempts to disturb the peace, quietness or right of privacy of any person with no purpose of legitimate communication whether or not a conversation ensues, commits a misdemeanour and shall, upon conviction, be liable to a fine of K1,000,000 and to imprisonment for twelve months.

The prohibition on press expression that undermines national solidarity shall not apply to news reporting that is accurate, balanced, and necessary to inform the public, even where the subject matter reflects societal divisions; no institutional sanction shall be imposed in such cases.

Private persons may discuss or critique health policies using unverified information where they expressly disclose uncertainty and do not present assertions as established fact; no institutional sanction applies to such good-faith commentary.

Offence and punishment for deteriorating law and order, etc.—(1) If any person intentionally publishes or transmits anything in website or digital layout that creates enmity, hatred or hostility among different classes or communities of the society, or destroys communal harmony, or creates unrest or disorder, or deteriorates or advances to deteriorate the law and order situation, then such act of the person shall be an offence. (2) If any person commits an offence under sub-section (1), he shall be punished with imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 (seven) years, or with fine not exceeding Taka 5 (five) lac, or with both. Article 39: Publication of rumours

Any person who, knowingly and through a computer or a computer system, publishes rumours that may incite fear, insurrection or violence amongst the population or that may make a person lose their credibility, commits an offence.

Upon conviction, he/she is liable to imprisonment for a term of not less than three (3) years and not more than five (5) years and a fine of not less than one million Rwandan francs (FRW 1,000,000) and not more than three million Rwandan francs (FRW 3,000,000).

Editors and publishers may not amplify or repeat discriminatory expression during live coverage, podcasts, or comment sections, whether generated by staff or by automated tools, except where necessary to document it for public scrutiny while simultaneously condemning it and limiting rebroadcast; non-compliance triggers institutional disciplinary measures.

News outlets shall refrain from amplifying false narratives that assert governmental illegitimacy when such content lacks verification by at least two independent sources, or else license suspension may be imposed.
